data.title: Top 10 Overview of The Best Dutch Movies
data.meta_description: Are you looking for some quality Dutch cinema? Check out our top 10 list of the best Dutch movies to watch!
data.text:
1) Alles is Liefde

Alles Liefde is a 2007 Dutch romantic comedy directed by Joram Lürsen. The film features a star-studded cast, including Carice Van Houten, Thom Hoffman, Monique Van De Ven, Pierre Bokma, and Barry Atsma. Although not directed by one of the iconic figures of Dutch Film History, such as Paul Verhoeven or Alex Van Warmerdam, Alles is Liefde still stands out as one of the best Dutch movies ever made. The film explores the idea of love in all its forms – romantic love, familial love, platonic love, and even self-love. It’s an actual social experiment that attempts to answer the age-old question of what love truly means. Carice Van Houten, who played a Jewish woman during the Dutch Resistance in Paul Verhoeven’s Black Book, delivers a captivating performance as the female lead. Sebastian Koch, a German actor known for his work in the Oscar-winning movie The Lives of Others, also appears. Alles is Liefde features a soundtrack that includes some of the biggest hits by Paul De Leeuw, a famous Dutch singer, actor, and television personality. The film won four Golden Calves, the most prestigious awards in the Dutch Film Industry, including Best Film, Best Director, Best Actor, and Best Actress.

Overall, Alles is Liefde is a delightful romp that has the ability to tug at your heartstrings. The film stands as a testament to the creativity and innovation that is a hallmark of Dutch Cinema.

2) Bruiloft in Aken

Bruiloft in Aken, a Dutch movie directed by Pieter Kuijpers and starring Huub Stapel, Antonie Kamerling, Yorick van Wageningen, Daniël Boissevain, and Jan Bijvoet, was released in 1987. The film, set in the late 1960s during the Nazi occupation and resistance movement, follows a Dutch teenager, Flix, who visits Aachen, Germany, and falls in love with a German woman named Sybille. This horror film, based on a novel by Gerard Reve, explores themes of love, culture, and identity amidst the backdrop of significant historical and social change in Europe. It captures the spirit of rebellion and cultural upheaval that marked Dutch history during that era, reflecting protests and clashes between young people and the establishment. The novel, initially scandalous for its explicit depictions of sexuality and homosexuality, was adapted into this daring and commercially successful movie that retains its bold and provocative nature, directed by renowned Dutch filmmaker Pieter Kuijpers. The film, featuring Dutch women in prominent roles, remains relevant and impactful, solidifying its status as a classic in Dutch cinema and earning commercial success tenfold.

Bruiloft in Aken is an excellent example of a thought-provoking and entertaining Dutch cinema. It is a movie that captures an essential moment in Dutch history and provides a glimpse into the cultural changes at the time.

3) De Tweeling

De Tweeling (The Twins) is a powerful and emotionally-charged Dutch movie that tells the story of two twin sisters, Lotte and Anna, who are separated at a young age and raised in different families. The film is based on the novel of the same name by Tessa de Loo. The story begins in the 1920s when the twins are six and their parents pass away. Lotte is taken in by their uncle in the Netherlands, while Anna is sent to live with relatives in Germany. The girls grow up in different environments and are raised with different values, traditions, and beliefs. As adults, Lotte (played by Thekla Reuten) and Anna (played by Nadja Uhl) reunite and must come to terms with their differences and past traumas. The film explores themes of family, identity, loss, and reconciliation. De Tweeling was released in 2002 and received critical acclaim, winning several awards at the Netherlands Film Festival. It was also selected as the Dutch entry for the Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. The film is a must-watch for anyone interested in exploring the complexities of family dynamics and the impact of historical events on individual lives. The powerful performances of the lead actresses and the stunning cinematography make this movie an unforgettable viewing experience.

4) Dikkertje Dap

Dikkertje Dap is a heartwarming children’s film that was released in 2017. The movie is based on a famous Dutch children’s song about a little boy who befriends a giraffe named Raf in a zoo. Together, they embark on exciting adventures and teach each other valuable life lessons. The film was directed by Barbara Bredero and stars Liam de Vries as Dikkertje Dap and Dolores Leeuwin as Raf the Giraffe. The story is beautifully filmed and perfectly captures childhood innocence and wonder. The friendship between Dikkertje and Raf is touching, and the movie will leave viewers feeling warm and fuzzy inside. One of the standout aspects of Dikkertje Dap is its strong cast. The young actors give outstanding performances, and their chemistry is palpable. The movie also features a memorable soundtrack perfectly capturing the film’s spirit.

Overall, Dikkertje Dap is a delightful family movie that will entertain audiences of all ages. It’s a charming film that reminds us of the importance of friendship and the wonders of childhood. Read more about the Dutch meaning.

5) Fanfare

Fanfare, a 1958 Dutch comedy film directed by Bert Haanstra, stands as a testament to Dutch cinematic excellence. Set against the backdrop of the picturesque Dutch countryside, this film brings to life the spirited rivalry between two brass bands vying for glory in a prestigious music contest within a small village. Haanstra’s visionary direction beautifully captures the essence of the local culture, much like the way Mike van Diem skillfully portrays the intricate details of Dutch life in his films. Though Fanfare embodies the charm of Dutch cinema, it transcends borders due to its universal themes of community and competition, much like American films that find resonance across diverse audiences.

The film’s enduring appeal owes much to its technical brilliance, akin to the mastery displayed by Fedja van Huêt in his roles, as well as the captivating soundtrack composed by Jan Mulder, echoing the haunting allure found in Dutch horror films. With its accolades both in the Netherlands and internationally, Fanfare has solidified its place as a classic, much like “Soldaat van Oranje,” continuing to captivate audiences and critics alike even after six decades since its premiere.

Yet, among the many reasons contributing to its timelessness, one cannot overlook the genius of Frank Lammers and Jan Decleir, whose contributions to Dutch cinema mirror the brilliance of “Antonia’s Line.” In a similar vein, the presence of Danny de Munk in this narrative exemplifies the enduring spirit of the film, reiterating its importance to anyone who appreciates outstanding cinema. Fanfare remains an essential watch for enthusiasts of comedy, drama, music, and breathtaking scenery—a true gem that echoes the excellence synonymous with Dutch directorial prowess. So, settle in, savor the moments, and relish in the brilliance of Fanfare, a masterpiece that resonates through generations.

6) Het Paard van Sinterklaas

Released in 2005, Het Paard van Sinterklaas (The Horse of Sinterklaas) is a charming Dutch film that follows the adventures of a young Chinese girl named Winky, who moves to the Netherlands with her family. The film is set around the Dutch holiday of Sinterklaas, a festive celebration similar to Christmas. Winky is enamored with Sinterklaas and is eager to participate in the holiday traditions. When she meets the gentle horse Sinterklaas rides on his journey from Spain to the Netherlands; she is convinced that it is a magical creature. Winky forms a bond with the horse, whom she names “Amigo,” and begins to care for him secretly. The film touches on friendship, belonging, and cultural differences, as Winky navigates life in a new country while staying true to her heritage. Het Paard van Sinterklaas received critical acclaim and was a box-office success in the Netherlands. It also won the Best Children’s Film award at the Dutch Film Festival. This heartwarming film is an excellent choice for families and those looking for a delightful story that showcases Dutch culture and traditions. Don’t miss out on the opportunity to watch this charming tale unfold!

7) Ja Zuster, Nee Zuster

Released in 2002, Ja Zuster, Nee Zuster is a Dutch comedy movie directed by Pieter Kramer. The film is a modern version of a famous Dutch television series aired in the 1960s. The movie’s plot revolves around the quirky residents of a nursing home facing eviction. The protagonist, Nurse Klivia (played by Loes Luca), decides to take matters into her own hands and fights against the eviction notice. In doing so, she clashes with the grumpy landlord (played by Paul Kooij) and forms an unlikely friendship with a charming thief (played by Tjitske Reidinga). Ja Zuster, Nee Zuster is a heartwarming and feel-good movie that celebrates friendship and standing up for what is right. The movie received widespread critical acclaim and was a box office hit in the Netherlands. It was even selected as the Dutch entry for the Best Foreign Language Film at the 75th Academy Awards. If you’re a fan of classic comedies with a touch of nostalgia, Ja Zuster, Nee Zuster is a must-watch Dutch movie. The cast’s witty humor and delightful performances make it a timeless classic that all generations can enjoy.

8) Kinderjaren

Kinderjaren is a Dutch film released in 1988 and directed by Jindra Markus, a notable Dutch director known for exploring profound human experiences. This movie tells the story of a young girl named Tjitske who grows up in a rural village in the north of the Netherlands. Tjitske’s family struggles to make ends meet, and she must face many challenges growing up. Despite its dark themes, Kinderjaren is an excellent film that beautifully portrays the harsh realities of rural life in the Netherlands during the early 20th century. Markus, known for his knack in capturing nuanced emotions, skillfully navigates the narrative, revealing the intricate layers of Tjitske’s life. The film won several awards, including a Golden Calf for Best Supporting Actor for Peter Tuinman’s exceptional performance as Tjitske’s father. Kinderjaren, a masterpiece in Dutch cinema, captivates audiences with its poignant storytelling and evocative cinematography. It’s a must-watch for cinephiles passionate about exploring the depths of human experiences through the lens of history. Markus’s directorial prowess shines through as he unveils the haunting yet captivating journey of Tjitske, painting a vivid canvas of Dutch rural life rarely seen on screen. Watch it once, twice, or even ten times; each viewing unravels new layers of depth and emotion. If you’re a fan of dramatic and thought-provoking films, then Kinderjaren, an impeccable creation by a visionary director, is undoubtedly worth watching.

9) Nova Zembla

Nova Zembla is a Dutch movie that was released in 2011. It is a historical drama film about Willem Barentsz and his crew, who were stranded on the Arctic island of Nova Zembla in 1596. The film stars Dutch actors Doutzen Kroes and Derek de Lint in leading roles. The movie received mixed reviews, but it was praised for its cinematography, sound, and the cast’s performances. The breathtaking landscapes of Nova Zembla were captured in the film with great accuracy, making it an impressive visual experience. Nova Zembla also sheds light on the perseverance and resilience of the Dutch sailors who braved harsh weather conditions to discover new lands. It showcases their unwavering courage and determination to survive in one of the world’s most hostile environments.

Overall, Nova Zembla is an epic historical film that deserves to be seen. It accurately represents the Dutch explorers who changed the course of history. If you are a fan of historical dramas, then Nova Zembla should be on your watch list.

10) Pioniers van de Nieuwe Tijd

Pioniers van de Nieuwe Tijd, also known as New Times’ Pioneers, is a Dutch film released in 2019 that tells the story of a group of friends who meet each other while constructing the Afsluitdijk, a famous dam built in the 1930s to protect the Netherlands from flooding.

Peter-Jan Bogaert directs the movie and stars a cast of well-known Dutch actors, such as Gijs Blom, Susan Radder, and Sallie Harmsen. Pioniers van de Nieuwe Tijd portrays the struggles and challenges these young pioneers face as they embark on a dangerous and demanding journey to build a dam that will protect their country from the threat of the sea. The film’s impressive cinematography and captivating storyline are just a few reasons it has quickly become one of the best Dutch movies ever. Pioniers van de Nieuwe Tijd is an excellent movie in entertainment. It also highlights the courage and resilience of those who built the Afsluitdijk, which still stands strong today and is a testament to the Dutch’s unwavering determination in adversity.

Overall, Pioniers van de Nieuwe Tijd is an exceptional movie that successfully combines an intriguing storyline with fantastic visuals, great acting, and an inspiring message of perseverance, making it one of the top Dutch movies ever.
